No, and whoever thinks that Gandhi was not one of those responsible for Indian independence has not read much history. Gandhi was not SOLELY responsible for Indian independence — a lot of other players played roles in it. Gandhi’s idea of non-violence helped to shame the British into leaving. Many foreign writers like to think “oh, if the Nazis were there, Gandhi wouldn’t have won” — but forget that if the Nazis came or if the British were like General Dyer (Jallianwalla Bagh) all the time, then they would have been kicked out pretty quickly. The British ruled India through Indians. Gandhi’s brilliance was playing on British consciences and taking the moral high ground. By doing this, he was able to eliminate the divide-and-rule tactics and shame the English into leaving (you can’t very well claim to be fighting for democracy against the Germans if you don’t provide democracy to your colonies). But, as I repeat, Gandhi was not solely responsible

Thanks for the A2A. Yes, of course. In my opinion, attributing India’s independence to Mr Gandhi defies objective assessment, academic integrity and logic. India does not owe its independence to any single entity. The political conditions of the world was so arranged (WW2, British bankruptcy, INA revolt, the rise of anti-colonial USA and Soviet Union etc) that it was impossible for India to rot under imperialism anymore. Hence, the claim of British leaving India because of a sudden development of benevolence triggered by witnessing Mr Gandhi demonstrating a hazy, incoherent and inconsistent adherence to the concept of 'Ahimsa' is far fetched. An imperial power does not suddenly recede because of 'conscience issues'. I agree Mr Gandhi was an important leader who had played some part in awakening the masses and leading them sporadically. But he was neither originator of the the idea of passive resistance/boycott that he is generally credited for, nor was he able to efficiently execute this well-formed chosen strategy. The Bengal revolutionaries had laid out the entire strategy of Passive Resistance as a political movement to achieve independence in 1905–1910, much before Mr Gandhi arrived on scene and added his brand of ‘ahimsa’ to it. It is true that British entertained Mr Gandhi to a certain extent and he could successfully bargain with them, but even they stood firm against his pressure when their vital interests were at stake. The British kid gloved Gandhi and his supporters throughout, allowed them the funding and the functioning since they hardly saw it as a threat to their existence. Many high ranking British officials including Viceroys Chelmsford, Linlithgow and Puckle (Director general of Intelligence in 1940) regarded Gandhi as an "asset". Ellen Wilkinson, who was a member of the British Parliament for several years , remarked after her visit to India in 1932 as a member of the India League Deputation that "Gandhi was the best policeman the British had in India .
